Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Learning and Memory in Aged Common Marmosets
Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning and memory processes are believed to be similarly organized in human and nonhuman primates. Therefore, understanding human learning can be enhanced through behavioral and cognitive studies in nonhuman primates. Of particular interest are the effects of age on learning and memory, as age is indicated as a predominate risk factor for many neurodegenerative diseases. Compared to all other nonhuman primates, humans have remarkably increased life spans. This extended longevity is associated with a decline in cognitive function and increased susceptibility to neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer?s disease. Therefore, research that works to enhance knowledge of the mechanisms of aging, especially how it affects learning and memory, is of immense importance. This project will work to advance scientific understanding of the processes of aging through comparison with a nonhuman primate model (common marmosets). This research will be conducted at the Primate Research Institute (PRI) in Japan where an established colony of common marmosets presently resides. Research will be completed under the guidance of Dr. Katsuki Nakamura, whose expertise in cognitive neuroscience and aging in common marmosets will be invaluable to the project.

Common marmosets have been suggested as a new model for analysis of age-related changes as this species displays markers associated with neurodegeneration. However, the effects of aging are not well defined within common marmosets. Therefore, this project will be the first to examine the effects of age on cognitive function within common marmosets (Callithrix jacchus) through visual discrimination tasks and reversal learning. Four common marmosets, 10 years or older, will take part in this study. The results from this study will be compared to data collected from previous cognitive tests on a group of younger marmosets, ages 1 year 7 months to 4 years 3 months. Older marmosets are expected to not be able to complete the cognitive tasks at the same rate nor with the same level of success as the younger group. Importantly, this project will help elucidate the mechanisms of aging in relation to learning and memory. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
My EAPSI research was based on common marmosets, a small new world monkey species, that have been proposed as a new model for the study of age-related cognitive changes and neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s disease (AD). As a potential model for AD, one critical question that must be addressed is whether ageing has an effect on learning and memory in this species. For my EAPSI research, I wanted to examine learning and memory in a group of aged common marmosets. To do this, we employed object discrimination and reversal learning tasks. In object discrimination, the marmoset is presented two images. One image, Image A, is associated with a food reward and the second image, Image B, is not. The goal is for the marmoset to make an association between image A and the food reward. If the association was made, then it was determined that the animal had learned the task. In reversal learning, the marmoset once again was presented the same images as during the object discrimination task. However, now the food reward was associated with Image B. In this learning paradigm, the marmoset had to learn to inhibit its first learned response, picking Image A, and learn to now pick Image B. For both learning tasks, the number of errors committed before the animal reached criterion was recorded. These data were collected from 3 aged marmosets on a series of 4 object discrimination and 2 reversal learning tasks. These data were then compared to data previously compiled in a group of younger marmosets who had completed the same learning tasks at the Kyoto University Primate Research Institute (PRI), my host facility. Preliminary results indicated that the aged marmosets initially take longer to learn task rules, as they committed more errors in the first object discrimination and reversal learning task. However, once the aged marmosets learned the tasks, they were capable of completing them at the same rate as the younger cohort. 

The EAPSI fellowship allowed me to learn new research techniques. At the PRI, I learned how to conduct cognitive studies with living primates, something I had not previously known how to do. Therefore, this experience has made me a better researcher, one who is capable of proposing and answering research questions from different perspectives and with multiple techniques. Not only did it expand my research techniques but I also had the opportunity to work with many wonderful researchers and students at the PRI. I plan to maintain my relationships with them and continue to form collaborations in the future. Being in Japan helped to improve my interpersonal skills by allowing me to work within a culture outside of my own. 

Since my return from Japan, I have presented my EAPSI experience in a department wide lab meeting. I have also submitted an abstract and have been selected to present my research at Kent State University’s Graduate Research Symposium. We are currently working to expand the number of aged marmosets within the study. Once additional marmosets are added, we will plan to present our work at a research conference and begin writing a manuscript for publication. 

Overall, the EAPSI program has allowed me to grow as a researcher. It provided me with the opportunity to gain new research techniques and expanded my network for future collaborations. My EAPSI experience is something I greatly value.       

 


Last Modified: 03/14/2016
Modified by: Emily L Munger

As a potential model for AD, one critical question that must be addressed is whether ageing has an effect on learning and memory in this species. For my EAPSI research, I wanted to examine learning and memory in a group of aged common marmosets. To do this, we employed object discrimination and reversal learning tasks. In this learning paradigm, the marmoset had to learn to inhibit its first learned response, picking Image A, and learn to now pick Image B. For both learning tasks, the number of errors committed before the animal reached criterion was recorded. Preliminary results indicated that the aged marmosets initially take longer to learn task rules, as they committed more errors in the first object discrimination and reversal learning task. At the PRI, I learned how to conduct cognitive studies with living primates, something I had not previously known how to do. Overall, the EAPSI program has allowed me to grow as a researcher. It provided me with the opportunity to gain new research techniques and expanded my network for future collaborations.
